6. To improve understanding of outcomes of critical concern to many in gun policy debates, the U.S. government...should support research examining the effects of gun laws on a wider set of outcomes: crime, defensive gun use, hunting & sport, officer-involved shootings & industry.

Recommendation 5. Given current limitations in the availability of federal support for gun policy research, private foundations should take further steps to help fill this funding gap by supporting efforts to improve and expand data collection and research on gun policies.

Recommendation 4. To improve understanding of the real effects of gun policies, Congress should consider whether to lift current restrictions in appropriations legislation, and the administration should invest in  rearm research portfolios at the CDCP, the NIH, & the NIJ.

Recommendation 3. States that currently do not require a background check investigating all types of mental health histories that lead to federal prohibitions on  firearm purchase or possession should consider implementing robust mental illness checks.

Recommendation 2. When considering adopting or re ning child-access prevention laws, states should consider making child access to firearms a felony; there is some evidence that felony laws may have the greatest effects on unintentional  firerearm deaths.
Recommendation 1. States without child-access prevention laws should consider adopting them as a strategy to reduce firearm suicides and unintentional  firearm injuries and deaths.

@FrancesRobles The article is incredibly important and highlights a serious deficiency in our death reporting methods for calculating deaths from this disaster. I was just trying to make the point that statistical trends are not enough. There needs to be a forensic analysis to correct this.

@FrancesRobles When a death investigation system is overwhelmed it is often not uncommon for them to decline cases of deaths in the elderly or sick because those are not unexpected deaths. But if the circumstances are such that trauma was noted by family - there should be an autopsy.
@FrancesRobles If the case wasnt even reported to the ME and was assumed to be natural just because the person was old & sick, thats a problem with the death investigation system.

@FrancesRobles The point I was trying to make (and forgive me if I wasnt clear) was that it would help if a forensic expert reviewed the individual cases that make up these numbers: not just death certificates but photos, med records & autopsies

@FrancesRobles Got it. All he said was I think theres fairly compelling evidence that that increase is probably due to the hurricane, the Probably doesnt sound like he reviewed the individual cases just the overall trend.
@FrancesRobles @JLSigman Because the article didnt clearly mention autopsies or whether the medical examiner was notified.
